1558366.title: 219 W. 42nd St. (Seventh Avenue - Eighth Avenue)
1558366.folder: 219 W. 42nd St. (Seventh Avenue - Eighth Avenue), Manhattan, NY

713088f.text:
42nd Street, west from Eighth Avenue.
April, 1925.
Brown Brothers.

710181f.text:
667 to 671 Eighth Ave., west side, between West 42nd and 43rd Streets, showing an excavation where No. 669 formerly stood. The Corn Exchange Bank will erect a 1arge structure around the corner on 42nd Street and utilize this space as an ell to same. The other structures shown remain the same today (1938). This set consists of a negative and a positive.
December 3, 1926.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

713082f-a.text:
Turin Restaurant and Tecumseh Club, 315 West 42nd Street, north side, west of Eighth Avenue. This is the regular Democratic organization of the Fifth Assembly District South.
September 22, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

713083f-a.text:
317-305 West 42nd Street, north side, west of Eighth Ave.
September 22, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

713099f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from No. 327 between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, showing Holy Cross Church (Roman Catholic), Holy Cross Academy, and the new Commodore Hotel at 351-359 West 42nd Street.
May 20, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

713078f-a.text:
Brownstone house, 253-257 West 42nd Street, north side, east of Eighth Avenue, called "The Clinton." Prior to 1883 it was the Methodist Old Ladies' Home. As shown here it is shortly to be
demolished.
March 10, 1929.
P.L. Sperr.

713081f-a.text:
265, 261, 259, 257, 251 West 42nd Street, at and adjoining the N.E.corner of Eighth Avenue.
March 10, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

713077f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, west from No. 243, east of Eighth Avenue.
February 3, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

713086f-a.text:
Franklin Savinga Bank, Loew's American Theatre, and Wallack's (formerly Harris) Theatre, 42nd Street, at and adjoining the
S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue.
May 27, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

713089f-a.text:
Times Theatre, 42nd Street at the S.W. corner of Eighth Avenue.
July 25, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

713096f-a.text:
42nd Street, south side, at Ninth Avenue and towards Eighth. The McGraw Hill Building, No. 330, is in the later stages of construction. It fronts on the south side of 42nd Street and on the north side of 4lst Street, and stands directly at what was once the junction of Fitz Roy Road and Lake Four Lane.
April 6, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

713080f-a.text:
259, 26l, 263-265 West 42nd Street, adjoining and at the N.E.
corner of Eighth Avenue.
February 19, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710180f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue, north from and including 42nd Street. The view is
obstructed by the two clowns in the foreground.
June 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

713095f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, west from, but not including Eighth Ave. Prominent building shown on the south side, is the Magraw Hill Building. Note
Elevated Station of the Ninth Ave. Line.
June 21, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

713084f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, north side, at Eighth Ave.
November 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

713098f-a.text:
West 42nd Street, south side, west from (No. 320) but not including Eighth Ave., to and including Ninth Ave., showing prominently the 35-story McGraw-Hill Building, No. 330. Also shown is a general view in a southwesterly direction of the surrounding area with the Hudson River and the New Jersey shore discernible in the background.
1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

1507899-a.title: 42nd Street (West) - Eighth Avenue - Ninth Avenue
1507899-a.folder: 42nd Street (West) - Eighth Avenue - Ninth Avenue, Manhattan, NY

713079f-a.text:
Wallack's (formerly Harris) Theatre No. 258, and the north wing of the American Theatre, No. 260, which is ending its days as a burlesque house: West 42nd Street, adjoining the S.E. corner
of Eighth Avenue.
July 10, 1932.
P.L. Sperr.

713085f-b.text:
(1)
West 42nd Street, north side, west from and including Eighth Ave. The view shows buildings on the N.E. corner of Eighth Ave., being demolished.
May 21, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2 & 3)
A detail of view 1, showing the new structure erected at the N.E. corner. View No. 3 is in the opposite direction and shows only the corner.
September 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

343, 333, 329, 327-325 West 42nd Street, north side, between Ninth and Eighth Avenues: Holy Cross Academy, Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, and the houses adjoining and east
of the church. No. 329 is the church office.
September 22, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

713094f-a.text:
42nd Street, north side, from Eighth to Ninth Avenues, inclusive. The City Subway (Independent System) is under construction
under Eighth Avenue.
February 1, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

710187f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, from W. 42nd to 43rd Streets. Note the Corn Exchange Bank Building forming an ell to front on both 42nd Street and the Avenue. View 2 is taken across the cleared N.E. corner. View 3 is limited to the Boyertown Building at the S. W. corner of 43rd Street. Construction timbers appearing are shoring,utilized during subway construction.
View 1: February 19, 1933
View 2: November 9, 1936
View 3: October 14, 1927
P. L. Sperr

710187f-a.text:

710182f-a.text:
Moyerton Building. 671 8th Ave
The funeral of Freddie Welsh
Source: Horning Telegraph. N.Y.

710183f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue, east side, at 42nd Street and north.
June 4, 1933.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

710185f-b.text:
(1)
660, 662, 664, 666 Eighth Avenue, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of 42nd Street. No. 664 is one of the few remaining frame houses in the Times Square district.
June 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle.
May 1, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, after demolition. The 1-story building (in the centre) occupied by the United Cigar Stores Company is the only floor left of what was formerly a 3-story building. The upper two stories were demolished together with the other buildings which occupied this site.
July 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
